column1: Baytown is a city within Harris County and partially in Chambers County in the Gulf Coast region of the U.S. state of Texas. Located within the Houston–The Woodlands–Sugar Land metropolitan area
column2: it lies on the northern side of the Galveston Bay complex near the outlets of the San Jacinto River and Buffalo Bayou. It is the sixth-largest city within this metropolitan area. Major highways serving the city include State Highway 146 and Interstate 10. As of 2010
column5: and it had an estimated population of 77

column1: White settlers first arrived in the now-Baytown area in 1822. One of its earliest settlers was Nathaniel Lynch
column2: who set up a ferry crossing at the junction of the San Jacinto River and Buffalo Bayou. The still-operating ferry service is known as the Lynchburg Ferry. Other early settlers of Baytown included William Scott
column3: one of Stephen F. Austin's Old Three Hundred
column4: and Ashbel Smith
column5: who owned a plantation in the area.

column1: The city now known as Baytown was originally three separate towns. The first of these was Goose Creek
column2: named for the bayou of the same name where Canada geese wintered and whose name is still reflected in the area's Goose Creek school district
column3: whose establishment dates back to before 1850. With the discovery of the Goose Creek Oil Field
column4: the rival communities of Pelly in the late 1910s
column5: and East Baytown in the early 1920s
column6: developed as early boomtowns. The "East" in East Baytown was later dropped because it was west of Goose Creek.Serious talk of merging the three cities began shortly after World War I
column7: but the community of Baytown was opposed to this idea. However
column9: the three cities finally agreed to consolidate. The citizens settled on the name Baytown for the new combined city. Baytown as it is known today was officially founded January 24
column11: the Humble Oil and Refining Company
column12: founded by one-time Texas governor Ross S. Sterling and his associates
column13: in developing the Goose Creek Oil Field
column14: built the first offshore drilling operation in Texas and the second in the United States. The company later built the Baytown Refinery
column15: which would become one of the largest Exxon refineries in the world. Since then
column16: many other refineries have been built in the area. Exxon-Mobil is still one of the major employers in the city and now runs over 10 plants in the area including a newly announced 2 billion dollar expansion to its chemical facilities in 2019.

column1: Following the discovery of oil nearby
column2: the population of Baytown and the Tri-Cities boomed. Many immigrants arrived in Baytown
column3: among them a number of Jewish families who founded a synagogue
column4: K’nesseth Israel
column5: in 1930.Steel manufacturing in Baytown began in 1970 when United States Steel opened the Texas Works near the city.  The plant was officially closed in July 1986
column6: due to a poor economic climate and the decline of American steel in the 1980s.  The mill was later purchased by Jindal Steel and now operates as JSW Steel USA

column1: Baytown is located at the mouth of the San Jacinto River on Galveston Bay
column2: 26 miles (42 km) by road east of Houston.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 36.5 square miles (94.6 km2)
column3: of which 35.4 square miles (91.8 km2) is land and 1.1 square miles (2.8 km2)
column5: is covered by water.Baytown is located on the Gulf coastal plain
column6: and its vegetation is classified as temperate grassland and marshes. The municipalities have been built on reclaimed marshes
column9: which are all still visible in undeveloped parts of the Bay Area. Baytown is bordered by water on three sides. Along the south and west is Galveston Bay. On the east is Cedar Bayou. The city is roughly bordered along the north by Interstate 10. Portions of the city to the east of Cedar Bayou lie in Chambers County.

column1: Flatness of the local terrain and proximity to the bay have made flooding a recurring problem for the area. Baytown and surrounding communities once relied on groundwater for its needs
column2: but severe land subsidence has forced much the city to turn to ground-level water sources.

column1: The land beneath Baytown consists of layers of sand and clay to great depths. These layers were created by millennia of river-borne sediments which gradually incorporated plant and animal matter
column2: creating the petroleum deposits for which the Gulf Coast is now known.The region around the city has numerous faults
column4: but none has produced significant earthquakes in recorded history. These faults tend to move at a smooth rate in what is termed "fault creep"
column5: which reduces the risk of an earthquake. The one significant earthquake that has been reported in the area was the result of an underground water and petroleum extraction.

column1: Baytown's climate is classified as humid subtropical (Cfa in Köppen climate classification system). Spring supercell thunderstorms sometimes create tornadoes (but not to the extent found in tornado alley). Prevailing winds from the south and southeast bring heat from the deserts of Mexico and moisture from the Gulf of Mexico.Summer temperatures typically have highs near 90 °F (32 °C) though higher temperatures are not uncommon. The city's proximity to the bay and the winds that it generates moderate the area's temperatures and ease the effects of the humidity
column2: creating a more pleasant climate than inland communities like Houston. Winters in the area are temperate with typical January high of 61 °F (16 °C) and lows are near 42 °F (6 °C). Snowfall is rare. Annual rainfall averages exceed 53 inches (130 cm).Excessive ozone levels can occur due to industrial activities; nearby Houston is ranked among the most ozone-polluted cities in the United States. The industries located along the ship channel and the bay are a major cause of the pollution.Hurricanes are a substantial concern during the fall season. Though Galveston Island and the Bolivar Peninsula provide some shielding
column3: Baytown still faces more danger than Houston and other inland communities
column4: particularly because of storm surge
column5: as well as severe land subsidence in some low-lying areas of town due to excess pumping of groundwater in the 1960s (see Brownwood subdivision)  by area refineries and municipalities.  Hurricanes Carla (1961)
column6: Alicia (1983)
column8: and Harvey (2017) were the four most damaging hurricanes to affect Baytown.

column1: The centerpieces of Baytown's economies are three industrial districts the city has created
column2: all outside the city limits but within its extra-territorial jurisdiction. These districts primarily support petroleum and petrochemical processing. The anchors of the business community are ExxonMobil
column4: and Chevron Phillips. The ExxonMobil Baytown Complex
column5: founded in 1919
column6: is one of the world's largest industrial complexes. The Baytown Refinery located there is the largest in the United States. The Covestro (former Bayer MaterialScience) Baytown Industrial Park is the largest of Covestro's U.S. chemical processing sites producing a variety of petrochemical products. The Cedar Bayou plant
column8: is Chevron Phillips Chemical's largest manufacturing site in the United States. is a newer and growing industrial district which is quickly acquiring new tenants such as Jindal Steel and Power Limited and Samson Controls.In addition to the heavy industry in the business community
column9: Baytown is home to the Cedar Crossing Industrial Park. With a total expanse of 15
column11: Cedar Crossing Industrial Park is considered the world's fifth largest industrial park and the largest on the Gulf Coast. Cedar Crossing has attracted many top-tier companies with significant operations
column14: Walmart's 4.2 million-square-foot import center (their largest in the U.S.)
column15: JSW Steel's plate and pipe manufacturing facilities
column16: and Borusan Mannesmann's $148 million steel pipe manufacturing facility. Other occupants include Exel

column1: The Downtown Arts District is home to a plethora of different arts and cultures programs such as the Baytown Little Theater
column2: Lee College Performing Arts Center
column4: and the Baytown Public Art Program.

column1: The Baytown Little Theater is a community theater in Baytown run entirely by volunteers. The theater has been in operation for more than 55 years and is one of the longest continuously running community theaters in Texas. The theater typically produces six shows each year from September to August
column2: with each show giving seven performances. The Baytown Little Theater is known for their summer musical. Past performances include The Wizard of Oz and Disney's Little Mermaid.

column1: The Lee College Performing Arts Center hosts a number of theater performances
column2: symphony performances
column3: and art exhibits year around. The Baytown Symphony Orchestra
column4: in residence at Lee College Performing Arts Center
column5: performs several concerts throughout the year for the enjoyment of the public.

column1: The Art Gallery of Baytown is also in the Downtown Arts District
column2: and houses the Art League of Baytown. The Art League was organized in 1954 and incorporated as a Texas non-profit corporation in 1963. The gallery features works of art created by local artists. There is also a variety of gifts available for purchase such as paintings
column4: jewelry
column5: stained glass
column6: photos

column1: In the Downtown Arts District is the roots of the Baytown Public Art Program spearheaded by the City of Baytown Tourism Division. Overseeing the program is the Public Art Visioning Committee with members from the Art League of Baytown
column2: Lee College Art Department
column4: Parks and Recreation Department
column5: and the Baytown Tourism Division. Finding inspiration in Peter Kageyama book Love Where You Live
column6: the committee's vision for this program is to create emotional connections between residents of Baytown with their community
column7: building on the mantra “love where you live
column8: ” in hopes this love will be contagious to everyone who visits Baytown.

column1: The first phase of the program included three mural projects at different locations along Texas Avenue. The Sterling Municipal Library's mural Solitary Journey was the first completed mural by Armando Castelan. Located on the back corner of the library on W. Texas Avenue
column2: this is a life-sized book shelf. The second completed mural is at the Art League of Baytown. The artist
column4: used a trompe l’oeil painting style. The third project is the Umbrella Alley. In the beginning
column5: the alley was filled with broken concrete and graffitied walls. Now
column6: the Umbrella Alley is occupied with colorful umbrellas that swing back and forth
column7: casting shadows along the alley walls and ground. The Lee College Art Department is working on the mural that wraps around the walls that focus on the ecology of Baytown. The Eddie V. Gray Wetlands Education Center is home to another public art piece: a connex storage container transformed into a wooden cargo box containing an alligator and turtles. This mural was created to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the Wetlands Education Center. The Traffic Cabinet Mini Mural project has begun with the first Mini Mural traffic cabinet completed at Emmett Hutto Blvd and Baker Rd. More Mini Murals are lined up for 2019. A privately funded mural called Cruisin W. Texas Avenue has surfaced at Bay Area Auto Gallery on Texas Avenue. This mural features classic cars and Baytown icons like the Brunson Theater and Fred Hartman Bridge.

column1: Baytown has a council–manager form of government.  Rick Davis currently serves as the Baytown City Manager.  Brandon Capetillo is Mayor while council members are Robert Hoskins
column2: Chris Presley
column4: Charles Johnson
column5: Heather Betancourth
column6: and David Himsel.

column1: The City of Baytown operates the Sterling Municipal Library
column2: which has a collection of 300
column3: 000 items. The original Goose Creek Library opened in 1925; the first county library in Texas
column4: it was funded by the private donations of Humble Oil and Refining Company president Ross S. Sterling. The current Sterling Library was dedicated in 1963. The library's space increased to 50
column5: 500 square feet (4
column6: 690 m2) after bond programs in 1975 and 1995. In addition Baytown residents are served by the Harris County Public Library system.

column1: The United States Postal Service operates the Baytown Main Post Office at 601 West Baker Road and the Baytown Post Office "Station A" at 3508 Market Street.  The "Station A" designation is a leftover from Baytown's pre-consolidation days.  Prior to consolidation in 1948 each of the Tri-Cities
column2: (Baytown
column4: and Goose Creek)
column5: had their own post office.  After 1948 when the Tri-Cities consolidated under the name Baytown
column6: Goose Creek's post office became the main post office but they still needed a post office to service the rest of town so the Old Baytown Post Office became "Station A".Harris County Precinct Two operates Baytown Park
column8: at 4500 Hemlock Drive. Baytown Park includes two unlighted baseball/softball fields and toilets. The precinct also operates the Baytown Soccer Complex
column9: located north of Baytown at 9600 North Main Street in an unincorporated area. The complex has eight soccer fields; four are lighted and four are unlighted.Harris County Hospital District operates the Baytown Health Center in Baytown. The center opened on February 14
column10: 1967.Harris County operates a tax office at 701 West Baker Boulevard.

column1: Harris County Transit provides public transportation. The Baytown Park and Ride lot is located on the western side of San Jacinto Mall. Harris County Transit also offers a bus line that runs along Decker Drive
column2: Garth Road
column4: Baker Road
column5: and Rollingbrook Drive connecting most of Baytown's major shopping areas with Lee College.

column1: Greyhound Bus Lines operates the Baytown Station at Baytown Travel Express.Baytown Airport is a privately owned general aviation airport in unincorporated Harris County located north of Baytown. RWJ Airpark is a privately owned airport three miles (5 km) east of Baytown in Beach City. The closest airports with commercial airline service are William P. Hobby Airport and George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston.Baytown is served by Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County
column2: Texas (METRO) express route 236 Maxey Road/Baytown during the rush hours
column3: sending commuters to downtown HoustonBaytown is linked to Interstate 10 (see map) by State Highway 146 (Lanier Freeway) and Spur 330 (Decker Drive).  It is also linked by the Fred Hartman Bridge
column4: which crosses into the city from nearby La Porte; the bridge was built in 1995
column5: replacing the Baytown Tunnel
column6: to allow a deeper ship channel.

column1: East Harris County and West Chambers County are served by Lee College
column2: a two-year community college.

column1: Baytown is served by the Goose Creek Consolidated Independent School District. Based in Baytown
column2: the district has 14 elementary schools (grades K-5)
column4: 3 high schools (grades 9–12)
column5: a career center
column6: and two alternative centers for education. The district serves all of Baytown
column8: outlying areas of East Harris County
column9: and a small portion of western Chambers County. The three local high schools are Robert E. Lee (opened in 1928)
column11: and Goose Creek Memorial High School (opened in 2008).

column1: Stallworth Stadium is the home for varsity football and soccer for GCCISD as well as for the annual Bayou Bowl. The stadium seats approximately 16
column2: 000 fans
column3: making it one of the largest high school sports venues in the nation. It recently underwent a press box renovation in 2009
column4: as well as an innovation in 2006 when artificial turf and a huge scoreboard were installed. On a campaign stop for the 1976 presidential election
column5: President Gerald Ford attended a Robert E. Lee High School fall football game.
